Welcome to Seminar WR: PBE sectional’s documentation!¶

Contents:

  • Intro

module implementing the core classes used for representing a discrete NDF.

These classes are the top level Grid class and the lower level Section class. A Grid is a connected amount of sections. The sections are defined by their lower and upper boundaries (minimum, maximum), the pivot point and the number of particles within the section.

class WR.grid.Grid(start=0, end=1, particles=0.0)¶

Grid class for representing an arbitrary grid of connected sections.

The grid bins are represented by a list (actually a double ended queue) of N sections with arbitrary interval ranges. The seamless connection of the sections (max(bucket i) = min(bucket(i+1)) is guaranteed by the simple implementation of the classes methods. If changes are made to the Sections “by hand” the seamlessness has to be checked.

start end

0 1 2 3 ... N-1 N N+1 <- boundaries | 0 | 1 | 2 | 3 | ... | N-1 | N | <- pivots +–o–+–o–+—o—+-o-+–o–+–o–+—-o—-+->

[–o–) [—o—) [–o–) [—-o—-) <- section objects

left [–o–) [-o-) [–o–) right

Create a grid that adapts automatically to the given function.

static create_geometric(start, end, initial_step, factor, func=<function zero>, correct=True)¶

Create a geometric grid.

The grid is created using the given initial step size. By default the last section is corrected to match the given end value. This results in the last section not matching the exact end value. If this correction is turned off, the actual maximum of the grid will be greater than the given end value.

Parameters:
  • start – inclusive minimum of the grid.
  • end – exclusive maximum of the grid.
  • initial_step – step size of the first step in the grid.
  • factor – factor controlling size change.
  • func – particle number density function.
  • correct – flag for fixing numeric deviations in the last section.
Returns:

geometric Grid object.
static create_geometric_end(start, end, sections, factor, func=<function zero>, correct=True)¶

Create a geometric grid.

The grid is created by choosing an initial step size so the maximum boundary is the same as for the corresponding uniform grid.

Parameters:
  • start – inclusive minimum of the grid.
  • end – exclusive maximum of the grid.
  • sections – number of sections in the corresponding uniform grid.
  • factor – factor for size change.
  • func – particle number density function.
  • correct – flag for fixing numeric deviations in the last section.
Returns:

geometric Grid object.
static create_geometric_step(start, end, sections, factor, func=<function zero>, correct=True)¶

Create a geometric grid.

The grid is created by using the same initial step size as the corresponding uniform grid (step = (maximum - minimum) / amount). This method does NOT achieve the same maximum boundary.

Parameters:
  • start – inclusive minimum of the grid.
  • end – exclusive maximum of the corresponding uniform grid.
  • sections – number of sections in the corresponding uniform grid.
  • factor – factor for size change.
  • func – particle number density function.
  • correct – flag for fixing numeric deviations in the last section.
Returns:

geometric Grid object.

Parameters:

  • end – exclusive maximum of the grid.
  • sections – total number of sections in the grid.
  • func – number density function for calculating particle numbers.
  • correct – flag for fixing numeric deviations in the last section.
Returns:

equidistant Grid object.

class WR.grid.Section(start, end, particles=0.0)¶

Section class representing a discrete bin.

It represents the semi open interval [start, end). (minimum included, maximum NOT included in the interval). The class includes a fixed pivot within the sections boundaries (min <= pivot < max). The default pivot position is right in the middle between the min and max boundaries (pivot = min + size / 2). The length of the section (max - min) is called size. Additionally the class contains a field for the total number of particles in the section and the derived value of the mean particle density.

start pivot end
| |
—[——-o——-)–>
| |

v_i x_i v_i+1

Returns:section size (max - min).

Returns:inclusive minimum of the section.
WR.grid.find_initial_step(start, end, steps, factor, max_err=1e-14, max_iter=100)¶

Find initial step size for geometric grid with given parameters.

The Function tries to figure out an initial step size for a geometric grid with the given paramters (start, end, steps, factor). Its initial guess is the step size of the corresponding uniform grid. Further guesses are calculated from the ratio of the resulting and the desired length. The method converges very fast and is therefore slowed down by averaging to approach the solution slowly and achieving a more stable result.

Parameters:
  • start – start of the grid.
  • end – end of the grid.
  • steps – number of steps.
  • factor – geometric grid factor.
  • max_err – maximum allowed iteration error.
  • max_iter – maximum allowed number of iterations.
Returns:

initial step size (first cell) for the geometric grid.

module implementing the fixed pivot technique in a class.

The class handles the main calculation using the fixed pivot technique for breakage, aggregation, nucleation and growth. The different kernel functions can be arbitrarily defined by the user.

class WR.methods.CellAverage(initial, primary=0, secondary=1, bre=True, bre_freq=<function zero>, child=<function zero>, agg=True, agg_freq=<function zero>, gro=True, gro_rate=<function zero>, nuc=True, nuc_rate=<function zero>)¶
